objectives: Review core networking terms such as LAN, WAN, bandwidth, and latency.
Compare the OSI and TCP/IP models and trace encapsulation.
Install Packet Tracer and confirm a two-node topology can ping.
Create a repeatable note system for the entire program.
labs: Lab 1.1 – Basic LAN ping test with two PCs and a switch.
Lab 1.2 – Console into a 2960 switch and practice show commands.
Mini project – Diagram the home network and label the OSI layers in use.
milestones: One-page explanation of how data moves between hosts using the OSI view.
Packet Tracer screenshot plus a short summary of the ping test.
Packet Tracer and note workflow confirmed for continued use.

objectives: Study Ethernet framing, TCP vs UDP behavior, and ARP resolution.
Practice interface configuration and verification commands.
Capture traffic in Packet Tracer simulation mode to observe headers.
Complete short daily subnetting drills to build speed.
labs: Lab 2.1 – Apply basic switch hardening (hostname, passwords, management IP).
Lab 2.2 – Build a three-switch topology with trunks and inspect MAC tables.
Trace exercise – Record an ARP request and reply using a packet capture.
milestones: Three timed subnetting drills finished with at least 90 percent accuracy.
Short write-up describing the trunk test and MAC table observations.
Packet capture annotated with the key header fields.

objectives: Design IPv4 addressing plans with VLSM for small offices.
Configure IPv6 global, link-local, and loopback addresses.
Practice host configuration (PCs, switches, routers) for dual stack.
Keep flashcards for prefix lengths, masks, and host calculations.
labs: Lab 3.1 – Subnet a /24 into multiple VLANs and document the plan.
Lab 3.2 – Configure IPv6 on two routers and verify pings plus ND output.
Worksheet drill – Complete a set of random subnetting problems.
milestones: Addressing spreadsheet finished and peer-reviewed or self-checked.
Dual-stack ping test captured with command outputs.
Subnetting accuracy log maintained for the week.

objectives: Refresh wireless basics such as channels, security, and coverage.
Review visualization tools (mind maps, diagrams, flashcards).
Summarize lessons learned from Months 1–4 fundamentals content.
Take a small practice exam that mixes questions from weeks 1–4.
labs: Lab 4.1 – Build a small WLAN in Packet Tracer and test association.
Lab 4.2 – Capture IPv6 Neighbor Discovery traffic for review.
Practice exam – Complete a 50-question fundamentals quiz.
milestones: Wireless lab write-up that lists SSID, security choice, and results.
Mind map or visual summary covering all fundamentals topics so far.
Practice exam score recorded with weak topics flagged.

objectives: Configure VLANs, access ports, and voice ports on multiple switches.
Practice router-on-a-stick inter-VLAN routing.
Verify connectivity with show commands and per-VLAN pings.
Document standard naming and IP rules for campus access layers.
labs: Lab 5.1 – Create VLANs and assign access/voice ports.
Lab 5.2 – Configure inter-VLAN routing using subinterfaces.
Validation checklist – Record ping tests and interface summaries.
milestones: Access layer template documented for future labs.
Inter-VLAN routing test evidence stored with commands and pings.
Post-lab summary listing troubleshooting steps taken.

objectives: Review STP concepts (root bridge, port states, PortFast, BPDU Guard).
Build EtherChannel links with LACP and confirm load-balancing.
Map redundant switch topologies and expected forwarding paths.
Record show command outputs for STP and EtherChannel verification.
labs: Lab 6.1 – Configure Rapid PVST+ with a selected root bridge.
Lab 6.2 – Build a two-switch EtherChannel and test failover.
Observation log – Capture how STP reacts when links fail.
milestones: STP design notes with bridge priorities and interface roles.
EtherChannel testing report showing port-channel status.
Short quiz or flashcards covering key STP timers and behaviors.

objectives: Configure IPv4 and IPv6 static routes, including floating routes.
Implement HSRP or VRRP for gateway redundancy.
Practice troubleshooting for asymmetric routing and missing routes.
Log verification commands such as show ip route and show standby.
labs: Lab 7.1 – Build a dual-router edge with static routes and backups.
Lab 7.2 – Configure HSRP on two switches and test failover.
Troubleshooting drill – Break a static route and document the fix.
milestones: Routing table snapshots stored for normal and failure states.
HSRP state-change timeline recorded with ping evidence.
Troubleshooting checklist refined for future routing labs.

objectives: Review OSPF concepts: LSAs, DR/BDR, metrics, and areas.
Configure single-area OSPF on routers and switches with routed ports.
Verify adjacency states and SPF results with show commands.
Experiment with interface cost changes to influence path selection.
labs: Lab 8.1 – Build a three-router single-area OSPF topology.
Lab 8.2 – Adjust interface costs and observe route changes.
Packet capture – Inspect Hello packets to confirm neighbor settings.
milestones: Adjacency table recorded for every router in the lab.
Cost-change experiment documented with before/after routing tables.
Reflection paragraph summarizing OSPF lessons learned.

objectives: Configure DHCP pools, reservations, and relay agents.
Practice PAT and static NAT for inside networks.
Review supporting services such as DNS, NTP, and Syslog.
Collect command outputs that prove each service is operating.
labs: Lab 9.1 – Build a DHCP server and relay setup in Packet Tracer.
Lab 9.2 – Configure PAT plus one static NAT rule and test translations.
Service log – Enable Syslog or NTP and capture relevant output.
milestones: Address assignment table captured from the DHCP lab.
NAT translation table annotated with each test case.
Service verification commands stored for study notes.

objectives: Harden device access (secure console, VTY, and enable secrets).
Apply AAA concepts such as local users and role separation.
Practice Layer 2 security features: port security, DHCP snooping, DAI.
Draft a baseline security checklist for lab gear.
labs: Lab 10.1 – Secure console/VTY access and enable SSH-only management.
Lab 10.2 – Configure port security and DHCP snooping on access switches.
Checklist – Document every security control applied in the lab.
milestones: Security baseline template completed for future use.
Lab evidence showing blocked violations or snooping activity.
Reflection on remaining security gaps to tackle next.

objectives: Review automation basics: REST concepts, JSON, and YANG at a high level.
Use Python or another tool to send simple CLI batches to devices.
Experiment with Packet Tracer APIs or textFSM-style parsing.
Track repetitive tasks that could be automated later.
labs: Lab 11.1 – Write a small script that logs into a device and runs show commands.
Lab 11.2 – Parse command output and save structured data to a file.
Planning task – List top manual workflows that automation could improve.
milestones: Repository or folder created for automation snippets.
Sample script committed with comments on prerequisites.
Backlog of automation ideas prioritized by impact.

objectives: Review every CCNA domain with mixed quizzes and flashcards.
Run at least one full-length mock exam under timed conditions.
Capture weak-domain topics for targeted study in Month 5.
Plan rest days to avoid burnout before the capstone month.
labs: Mock Exam 12.1 – Full CCNA-style test with score analysis.
Lab 12.2 – Rebuild a mini network that touches routing, switching, and services.
Retrospective – Document study habits that worked best.
milestones: Mock exam report filed with focus areas for improvement.
Consolidated weak-topic list posted in the repo.
Updated study calendar for Month 5 deliverables.

objectives: Select a realistic network scenario for the capstone project.
Gather business, capacity, and security requirements.
Design high-level and low-level diagrams.
Create a bill of materials plus an addressing and VLAN plan.
labs: Design Task 13.1 – Draft physical and logical diagrams.
Design Task 13.2 – Build an addressing spreadsheet and VLAN list.
Risk review – List constraints, open questions, and test plans.
milestones: Capstone charter approved with scope, success criteria, and timeline.
Design packet (diagrams, IP plan, requirements) stored under the week folder.
Test checklist created for the implementation week.

objectives: Implement the capstone network in Packet Tracer or lab gear.
Validate routing, switching, services, and security controls.
Document test results with screenshots and command logs.
Track issues, fixes, and any design changes.
labs: Build Task 14.1 – Deploy the full capstone topology.
Build Task 14.2 – Execute the predefined test plan and capture evidence.
Change log – Record adjustments made during implementation.
milestones: Test report attached with pass/fail notes and remediation steps.
Updated diagrams reflecting the final build.
Lessons-learned summary for future projects.

objectives: Schedule the CCNA exam or final practice tests.
Run targeted drills for historically weak topics.
Prepare exam-day checklist (ID, Pearson VUE steps, rest plan).
Plan a short recovery window after the attempt.
labs: Mock Exam 15.1 – Final timed practice with score review.
Drill 15.2 – Flashcard or lab remix focused on weak areas.
Mindset task – Write a calm exam-day routine.
milestones: Exam booking confirmation saved in the repo or notes.
Improved mock exam score relative to Week 12.
Exam checklist finalized.

objectives: Refresh the resume with CCNA-focused bullet points.
Update LinkedIn, GitHub, and any portfolio pages.
Collect references or testimonials from mentors.
Write a concise professional summary.
labs: Profile Task 16.1 – Rewrite resume bullet points to quantify impact.
Profile Task 16.2 – Align GitHub README and pinned repos with networking goals.
Outreach list – Build a spreadsheet of target companies or contacts.
milestones: Resume vNext stored in PDF and DOCX formats.
Online profiles audited with before/after screenshots.
Reference list confirmed with contact info.

objectives: Collect common behavioral and technical interview questions.
Draft concise STAR-format answers for experience stories.
Re-create troubleshooting labs that mirror typical interview prompts.
Schedule mock interviews or study sessions.
labs: Interview Lab 17.1 – Simulate a helpdesk-to-network escalation scenario.
Interview Lab 17.2 – Practice rapid switch/router configuration from memory.
Question bank – Maintain a list of questions with practiced answers.
milestones: Mock interview feedback documented with action items.
Question bank reviewed and refined twice this week.
Troubleshooting lab notes exported for quick refreshers.

objectives: Identify job leads that fit the desired role and location.
Customize cover letters or intro emails for each lead.
Track application status in a simple Kanban or spreadsheet.
Stay active in networking communities or forums.
labs: Pipeline Task 18.1 – Build an application tracker with stages.
Pipeline Task 18.2 – Draft a reusable cover-letter template.
Community Task – Post or share one helpful networking insight.
milestones: Minimum of five tailored applications sent this week.
Tracker updated daily with responses or follow-ups.
Community engagement logged (forum, LinkedIn, meetups).

objectives: Review interview feedback and adjust answers accordingly.
Keep lab practice fresh with small daily scenarios.
Outline a continuous-learning plan beyond CCNA (CCNP, cloud, automation).
Maintain wellbeing habits to stay sharp for interviews.
labs: Lab 19.1 – Daily 30-minute troubleshooting sprint using older labs.
Lab 19.2 – Draft a 90-day learning roadmap for the next certification or skill.
Reflection journal – Capture lessons from each interview round.
milestones: Learning roadmap published in the repo.
Interview adjustments documented after every conversation.
Wellbeing checklist (sleep, breaks, exercise) reviewed each weekend.
